subject: Art
title: Collage Techniques
description: Combining paper, fabric, and found materials with paint.

hook.text: Cut paper, torn magazine pages, fabric scraps, old letters â€” collage introduces real-world textures and imagery into painting. Picasso and Braque invented it in 1912, and it blew open what a painting could be.

buildup.text: Collage materials: newspaper, tissue paper (transparent layering), fabric, printed photos, maps, packaging, dried leaves, sand, and anything flat enough to adhere. Adhesive: matte medium (for paper), gel medium (for heavier materials).

discovery.text: Collage forces compositional thinking: you're arranging shapes, not drawing them. This is liberating â€” you can audition compositions by MOVING pieces before gluing. It's physical Photoshop, and the results have a tactile quality digital can't match.

twist.text: The power of collage: combining unrelated materials creates unexpected connections. A piece of a love letter under a painted ocean. A map fragment becoming a landscape. The juxtaposition creates meaning that neither element has alone.

climax.text: Gather 10 different paper materials (newspaper, colored paper, old book pages). Cut/tear them into shapes. Arrange a landscape composition without drawing. Glue it down, then paint over parts. Collage + paint = more than either alone.

punchline.text: Collage breaks the tyranny of the blank canvas. You start with existing materials and transform them â€” creation from curation.

quiz.question: What is collage's unique advantage for compositional planning?
options: You can physically move and rearrange pieces before committing, auditioning compositions in real time
